Bluebird’s Limitations: No Generative Practice: -Memorizing "I ate rice" doesn’t teach you to create "She will cook soup" unless the app trains sentence structure manipulation. Limited Contextual Variety: -Pre-set phrases may not cover diverse scenarios (e.g., storytelling, hypotheticals), leaving gaps in applying tenses flexibly. Passive Learning: Focuses on recognition/repetition, not active creation of sentences.

Let me offer a helpful opinion, if I may. This app provides an engaging path to learning some modalities of French. But I think the design has parameters that are undesirable, to say nothing about price. Essentially, there is no option to advance faster than the lessons, so if you have trip planned in 3 months and you're motivated to learn, you'll be held back. If a foundational knowledge of French, you can't grow. At $1 each (with deals), it's expensive. And you can't cancel anytime.

Great UI, much better than Duolingo. Solid clean aesthetic design, good self-pacing, and really helpful vocab review system. I like how it's not gameified; instead of feeling like I'm playing a meaningless game/gambling, I'm actually intentionally learning (and still having fun!). I like the culture notes in between lessons too. And the best part? No ads using your library card!

My favorite language learning app by far! I love how it provides context and explanations to why certain sayings are used over others and explaining additional things about the culture and language. I feel that most language learning apps don't inherently provide that information, which can be pivotal to truly understand not just how something is said, but WHY. Tip: check with your local library to see if you can get full free access with your library card!

I love that it allows you to use your own reasoning to figure out a slight variation of words and phrases based on what you learned. AND that it give grammer and cultural explanations within each lesson

I very much enjoy this language app. I appreciate how it introduces conversations by native speakers in practical contexts, and then walks you through it, step by step. By the end of the unit, it's almost kinda amazing that I can understand a conversation that was previously foreign to me. Thanks for a very useful app, Mango team!
I find it much more practical than Duolingo. I'm already able to make some small talk with my Italian patients.

Your experience will mostly be determined by your level, so far I would not recommend it for a beginner. I started off what's Spanish which I had a fair amount of familiarity with I wanted to advance and for that it's been very useful. I've now started Japanese for which I'm a complete beginner and even at level zero they'll ask you to put full sentences together after teaching you literally five words. I keep hoping there's a method to the madness but so far it hasn't come together.
I use it before work sometimes just to warm up my speaking.

One of the most blatant attempts at throwing AI into it and walking away. Much worse than duolingo. This app is in testing, but they don't tell you that. They let you pay for it, then use an app that breaks constantly and the exercises are pretty clearly AI generated and just randomly incorrect. I am basically paying to test their product and have requested my money back. Go watch 3 Spanish YouTube videos and have a stray dog bark at you, same experience.
really good.

There are content bugs every lesson. The AI "conversations" are scripted (you're given the written version of how the program wants you to respond), and don't even make sense (just a string of random often unrelated sentences). It's not at all what was advertised, as "speaking on day 1" aside from "voice recognition while reading what is written on the screen." Each new vocabulary word has a picture; I find my brain using the picture/ overriding learning the Spanish word. Stick to Duo Lingo.
Feels more useful than memorizing random words.

Shady billing practices. They upsell add-ons that cost more than the core product, set a strict no-refund policy, then fail to send subscription renewal reminders so you get a bill shock when you look at your card statement. The app was quite buggy so I stopped using it, forgot about it, and am now one of many people (given the reviews) who has experienced this issue. Stay away.

We’ve only been using Khan Academy Kids for a short time, but I’m really impressed. I wanted educational screen time that felt worthwhile for my toddler. The app is completely free, has no ads, and includes a great mix of videos and interactive learning. Some repetition, but that works well for kids. Minimal glitches so far. It’s a great complement to preschool for early reading, math, and foundational skills.

I love this app as an ad-free option for allowing interactive, game-like screen time. The content is thoughtfully curated and usually involves building levels of skill in each area. There is alot of repetition, which I appreciate and my child doesn't seem to mind. I like that the visuals are relaxing and the pacing is slower than other generic children's content, even for exciting themes. A few of the instructions aren't 100% clear, but not a big deal. Access to the full library is a big hit!

This app is honestly remarkable. Exactly what I needed to expand my french vocabulary and I find I am actually remembering the words it trains me. I also love that you can add your own words very simply (and that it's obvious which are your own and which are theirs), and I find the chat bot so incredibly useful - allows you to do various exercises at your own pace and the bot corrects the mistakes you make by explaining why what you said was incorrect (i.e. like a real teacher!).

Edit: Developer solved a technical issue very quickly. App functions well and better than most others I've tried. Original: This app is an active scam. Do not buy it! App is fully featured in the free trial. However, when purchase premium, you find half the features are still locked behind a yearly subscription. To be clear, this is a 40 EUR one time payment, followed by a 50 euro yearly subscription, and users are deliberately misled into believing it's a one time payment.

This app is pure bunk! Try not speaking a quiet room and see what score that app gives you on your pitch! 🤣🤣🤣🤣 I wanted to see if this spectrograph recording actually works. I recorded myself not speaking in a quiet room. I was not talking at all, and in the playback no language could be heard. I still routinely received 90-97 % pitch perfect on the words I 'attempted'. I'm not even sure we can trust the native speaker recordings.

I'm a native Japanese speaker and found the pitch scoring unreliable. While the system often gives robotic speech low score, it appears it rewards only a specific style of fluency and accent precision. When I carefully follow the style, scores reach 80–90%, but varied speech often drops to 60–80%, and occasionally 0%. Unnatural, mimicked "foreigner" pronunciation can score 90%, though usually around 70%. I don't believe aiming for high scores in this app leads to native-sounding Japanese.

So far it's great for what I need it for. But you have to use it with clear expectations. Relying on the % to teach insights past its capability will not help. A dev request, please create a section for minimal pair testing, like at kotu.io. This will greatly help beginners like me who have an extraordinarily hard time recognizing any changes in pitch for a single word, let alone a sentence. I've bought a lifetime pass for this and am excited to see this app evolve!
Unusable. Keeps crashing on my infinix phone

This is my favorite Japanese learning app as a heritage speaker who has trouble with speaking in general. I like that it actually gets me to practice speaking out loud when my tendency is to just practice in my head (bad habit and shyness lol). I do wish there were more tracking/progress markers for the vocabulary side. But overall, I am satisfied with my purchase.
Omg...this app is amazing. I downloaded it for my Japanese pronunciation, it's really useful guys..!!!

The pitch accent analysis doesn't work very well. I tried saying things completely wrong (understand, the opposite of what was required) and still never scored less than 80%. Having said that, the vocab seems useful and the recordings are good and you can still practice pronunciation even if the analysis doesn't work. So I might keep the year-long subscription. Edit: The analysis simply doesn't work. Among my 80+%-scoring attempts were some where I said the phrase in a totally flat pitch.

I have no idea why the ratings are lower on this app, maybe it went through some growing pains druing launch, but it's pretty great right now. The pitch accent training is extremely important, and this app does it's job very well. You can playback your voice, listen to native speakers, and see what accuracy your pitch is in a clear and concise way. The phrases provided are practical as well. It's a clean app, and it has a clean interface. I'm N4 level, and it's extremely helpful to me.

This app is a scam. I used the free 7 day trial then paid for a subscription. Once the 7 day trial finished and they took my money, the app stopped working. It won't go passed the initial screen. I've tried updating the app and contacting them, and nothing is being done to correct the problem. Save your money and don't get this app. Update: was given a 1 year subscription promo code but it didn't work and I was still going to be billed. When I contacted them regarding this, they ignored me.

(Updating my review) I purchased the lifetime access of the app and now I can say that is perfect with no issues! The intonation check really helps you understand how you pronounce the phrases compared to the correct pronunciation. It also includes real Japanese phrases that you don't want to miss. Thank you for your reply and for the development of this app. It's really good!

This is the first app I've discovered that enables you to practice speaking and test your ability to use pitch accent correctly. So happy that it has been created! My main concern is around the training, it seems to dive straight away into specific words and long sentences, a steady ramp up from basic would be useful. It would also be good if there were a feature to test cards added to one's personal deck, I can't see a feature to do that, meaning testing your ability is tricky.

Seems like it would be good for people moving to Tokyo, but if you speak Kansai-ben, this app is useless. I speak Osaka-ben, and according to this app, some things I pronounce are 'wrong', but in reality it's just my accent. It would be like telling a foreigner from Birmingham that they are pronouncing English words wrong because they don't sound like a foreigner. Ask someone from Tokyo how to pronounce「犬」, then ask someone from Tokyo. Both answers are right, but the tone shift is opposite.
